thread.title: Comments or healthy debate?

author: news24.com
title: Comments or healthy debate?
text:
With so much debate around the decision to disable the comments on News24, it occurred to me that there are many people who are more concerned with the loss of their ‘look at me and see how clever I am’ platform than with the loss of a healthy debating forum.
In theory, comments on articles or submissions should add to a debate, or at least give rise to healthy questioning on matters which directly concern citizens and their daily lives, in addition to providing information.
Internet trolls exist across the world, and the copy-editors who have to work through enormous volumes of content may possibly be breathing a sigh of relief at the possible reduction of their stress levels.
Yet, yet – will the disabling of the comment feature add to the website, or detract from it? There are many people who read the articles yet take more delight from seeing what the general public has to say on the matter, without necessarily leaving a comment themselves.
The one thing which bears examination is the fact that print media doesn’t offer the option of immediate comments, yet people continue to write to the editor to express their views. Not all letters are accepted, of course, but those which make it into print are published for their relevance and clarity of expression, surely, and in order to make a contribution to a subject or debate.
The internet and social media combined have had the effect of turning huge numbers of consumers into ‘immediate gratification’ junkies. That is exactly the word which describes the addiction to provoking ire, making inane comments and raising contentious issues by expressing direct and vicious attacks for no reason other than that they can. For that reason, the removal of the comments feature seems like a sensible idea.
Stating that the removal of comments is a direct attack on freedom of speech can only be said to be applicable when the publication or website in question becomes simply a mouthpiece for the government or ruling party.
